text: I think a lot of the hate for this game comes from people not being able to mentally do that separation.

author: Bhiner1029
text: It really seems that way. It‚Äôs so obvious to me that the game is criticizing the actions of its characters, but so many people have somehow concluded that the game is breaking the fourth wall and calling them a bad person simply for interacting with it.

author: -OrangeLightning4
text: I love the comparison that the player is an actor, carrying out the character's story. These are events that would happen whether we specifically are in control or not, we are just the vessel that allows the character to continue *their* journey.

author: Bhiner1029
text: That‚Äôs a fantastic way to put it. We‚Äôre carrying out the characters actions, but aren‚Äôt making any big choices for them. The characters are their own people with specific motivations and ideas, and it wouldn‚Äôt really make sense for the player to be able to act against those traits.

author: Sir__Walken
text:
This is literally every game that isn't some rpg that lets you make game altering choices. Every story in every game plays the same way and has the same restrictions. I love the last of us 2 and understand some people don't like it but this is a bs excuse for people not liking the game imo.

Maybe the fact that the characters actions are so polarizing is the reason they don't like the "forced" nature of them but every game still does it.

author: Bhiner1029
text: Yeah, that's exactly my point. Games where the player dictates every single choice that the character makes is not the norm. It's literally just Bethesa RPG's and stuff like that. I have no idea why so many people seem to act like it's some crazy thing that you don't get to make every single choice in TLoU2.

author: rnarkus
text: A portion of it, sure. What I see mostly are people have qualms with the overall story.

author: iWentRogue
text:
I‚Äôm completely aware >!that i‚Äôm not the one *directly* killing a dog, i think that goes without saying, the same way i know i‚Äôm not in a post apocalyptic world filled with cordycep zombies.!<

The fact that many people feel >!like it‚Äôs them killing the dog just speaks volumes of how much of a masterpiece the narrative is and what a great job it does at putting you in the main characters shoes.!<

That being said, >!**you** are killing the dog. If you don‚Äôt kill it, the story doesn‚Äôt progress. You‚Äôre controlling a character that without the players input, it doesn absolutely nothing so techincally their actions are yours.!<

Also, the other chokepoint >!dogs are unavoidable. The moment they spot you, they‚Äôre hostile, will attack you. So you have to kill them.!< This is just a silly comment to make about this kind of game considering the narrative is linear unlike choice RPG‚Äôs which allow the player to **not** do certain things and still progress the game.

author: Bhiner1029
text: I was just responding to your wording of the game ‚Äúmaking‚Äù you do these things. When I was playing it, I didn‚Äôt feel like the game was making me do anything. The one time that Ellie does kill a dog, it‚Äôs attacking her and she wouldn‚Äôt reasonably do anything else. Ellie is making these choices and the player interaction is there to hammer home the consequences of those choices.

author: iWentRogue
text:
I understand that, but if we want to get technical with the meaning of what you do as a player and how you‚Äôre forced to do things, we gotta take into account that if we don‚Äôt do certain things, the game won‚Äôt progress. You have to hold/tap Square >!otherwise the dog kills you.!<

Is all pre-determined by the writers so that you get the sense of guilt later on >!when you‚Äôre provided the dogs backstory!<

I understand that this is the **only** way the story progresses so the player is in a passenger seat position, but the fulfillment of Ellies actions are left for the player to finalize which means that the player is forced to participate in **that** action.

The one game that comes to mind that had a controversial mission but allowed the player to not participate and still progress the story was CoD: MW2 in the No Russian mission. In this mission >!you gun down an airport full of civillians, but you‚Äôre not forced to do it because the game allows you to skip the mission all together and progress the story.!<

author: Bhiner1029
text:
I think the player‚Äôs participation in those actions aren‚Äôt there as a way to make you feel guilty, but more as a way to highlight the things that Ellie is choosing to do. She has to actively make the choice to >!kill a dog, or torture someone!< and the button prompts make that clear. I really did not feel that any of that was there to make the player feel personally guilty on behalf of the character. This isn‚Äôt a game like Skyrim where the character and the player are interchangeable, and the use of multiple playable characters makes that even more clear.

Players are given choice to the limits of what that character might choose to do. In a normal combat encounter, Ellie could conceivably choose to set up traps to blow up every dog she sees, or choose to sneak by all of them to make things easier. >!But if a dog jumps at her when she opens a door, she isn‚Äôt going to choose to not kill it.!<
